projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: THE Garland OF Good-will.
div.p: Divided into Three parts, containing many pleasant SONGS, and pretty POEMS to sundry new NOTES.
With a TABLE to find the Names of all the SONGS. Written by T. D.
London, Printed for I. Wright, at the sign of the Crown on Ludgate-hill. 1678.

div.head: The Table.

list.head: In the First Part.
list.item: 5. Of the Duke of Cornwall's Daughter.
7. The banishment of the two Dukes.
8. The Noble Acts of Arthur of the Round Table, and of Lancelot du Lake.
9. A Song in praise of Women.
10. A Song in praise of a single life.
13. How a Prince of England Wooed the Kings Daughter of France, and how she was Married to a Forrester.
14. The Faithful Friendship of two Friends, Alphonso and Ganselo.

list.head: In the Second Part.
list.item: 3. A song between Truth and Ignorance.
5. In praise of the English Rose.

list.head: In the Third Part.
list.item: 1. A Maidens Choice 'twixt Age and Youth.
5. The Spanish Ladies Love to an English-man.
7. The Lover by his Gifts thinking to conquer Chastity.

div.head: A Mournful Ditty on the Death of Rosamond, King Henry the Second's Concubine.
div.opener: To the Tune of, When flying Fame.

lg.l: WHen as King Henry rul'd this Land,
Besides the Queen he dearly lov'd,
Most Peerless was her beauty found,
A sweeter Creature in this world,
Her crisped Locks like threads of Gold,
Her comely Eyes like Orient Pearls,
The blood within her Christial Ch • eks,
As though the Lilly and the Rose,
To whom Dame Elinor our Queen,
The King therefore for her defence,
At Woodstock builded such a Bower,
Most curiously this Bower was built,
That none (but with a Clew of Thread)
And for his Love and Ladies sake,
that was so fair and bright;
The keeping of this Bower he gave,
But Fortune that doth often frown,
The Kings delight and Ladies ioy,
For why the Kings ungracious Son,
But yet before our comely King,
The fairest Rose in all the world,
The Flower of my affected heart,
My Royal Rose, a thousand times,
For I must leave my fairest Flower,
And cross the Seas to famous France,
But yet my Rose be sure thou shalt,
And in my heart whilst hence I am,
i'le bear my Rose with me.
did hear the King say so,
The sorrow of her grieved heart,
And from her clear and christial Eyes,
Which like the Silver Pearled Dew,
Her Lips like to the Coral red,
did wax both wan and pale,
And for the sorrow she conceiv'd,
So falling down all in a swound,
Full oft betwixt his Princely arms,
And twenty times with watry eyes,
Why grieves my Rose, my sweetest Rose,
Because, quoth she, to bloody Wars,
But sith your Grace in Forreign Coasts,
Must go to hazard life and limb,
Nay, rather let me like a Page,
That on my Breast the blow may light,
O let me in your Royal Tent,
And with sweet Herbs refresh your Grace,
So I your presence may enjoy,
But wanting you my life is death,
Content thy self my dearest Love,
thy rest at home shall be;
In Englands sweet and pleasant Soyl,
Fair Ladies brook not bloody Wars,
My Rose in Woodstock-Bower shall rest,
While I amongst the pierceing Pikes,
My Rose in Robes of Pearl and Gold,
Shall dance the Galliard of my Love,
while I my Foes do tinite.
And you Sir Thomas whom I trust,
Be careful of my gallant Rose,
And there withal he fetcht a sigh,
as though his heart would break,
not one plain word could speak.
For at their parting well they might,
the King did see no more:
For when his Grace had past the Seas,
And forth she call'd this trusty Knight,
Who with his Clew of twined thread,
And when that they had wounded him,
the Queen his Thred did get,
But when the Queen with stedfast eyes,
She was amazed in her mind,
Cast off thy Robes from thee, she said,
And drink thee up this deadly Draught,
which I have brought for thee.
And pardon of the Queen she crav' • ,
Lake pitty on my Youthful Years,
And let me not with poyson strong,
I will renounce my sinful life,
Or else be banisht if you please,
to range the world so wide:
And for the fault that I have done,
Preserve my lif • , and punish me,
as you think fit to do.
And with these words her Lilly hands,
And down along her comely Cheeks,
But nothing could this furious Queen,
The Cup of deadly Poyson fill'd,
as she sat on her knee.
She gave this comely Dame to drink,
who took it from her hand,
And from her bended knees arose,
and on her Feet did stand:
And casting up her eyes to Heaven,
And drinking up this Poyson strong,
But when that death through every Limb,
Her chiefest Foes did plain confess,
Her Body then they did Entomb,
At Godstow, near to Oxford town,
as may be seen this day.

div.head: 2. A new Sonnet, containing the Lamentation of Shore's Wife, who was sometimes Concubine to King Edward the Fourth; setting forth h • r great Fall, and withal her most miserable and wretched end.
div.opener: To the Tune of, The Hunt is up.

lg.l: That lived late, in pompous State,
And now to Fortunes fair Dissimulation.
Brought in cruel and uncouth Plagues,
And at the Flower-de-luce in Cheapside,
The only Daughter of a wealthy Merchant-man
My heart or mind, to give or yield,
My Parents thinking strictly for to wed me,
Forcing me to take that which caused
The King commanded, I straight obeyed;
In all the Court, to none was such great report,
As unto me, though now in s • orn,
From the Court I was expelled,
The Duke of Glocester being Lord Protector,
A Cross before me there was carried plainly,
As a pennance to my former life,
On pain of death, I should not be harbour'd,
Which further more encreas'd my sorrow,
Most sumptuously brought to my Board,
Being full poor, from door to door,
I beg my Bread with Clack and Dish;
My Body soft, which the King embrac'd oft,
That wonted was in Bed of Down,
And you see, my finest Pillows be,
Of stinking Straw, with Dirt and Dung
My grievous fa • l bear in your mind,
Vow strange a thing, that the Love of a King,
Should come to dye under a Stall,

div.opener: To be sung in the old way, or else to the Tune of, Lebandalashot.

div.head: 4. How Coventry was made free by Godina, Countess of Chester.
div.opener: To the Tune of, Prince Arthur died at Ludlow.
div.l: LEofricus that Noble Earl,
of Chester as I read,
Did for the City of Coventry,
many a Noble deed:
Great Privilidges for the town,
this Noble man did get;
And of all things did make it so,
That they Tole-free did •• t:
Save only that for Horses still,
and did som • Custom pay▪
UUhich was g • eat 〈◊〉 unto the town▪
full long and many a 〈◊〉
UUherefore • is wife 〈…〉
That therefore he would make it fre • ,
as well as all the rest▪
So when she long: had sued,
her purpose to obtain;
Her Noble Lord at length she look,
within a pleasant vein:
And unto him with smiling chear,
s • e did forthwith proc •• d;
Entreating greatly that he would,
perform that Godly deed.
You move me much, my fair, (quoth he)
your suit I fain would shun▪
But what will you perform and do,
to have this matter done?
UUhy, any thing my Lord (quoth s • e)
I will perform it with good will,
if I my wish might have:
If thou wilt grant the thing, he said,
what I shall now require;
As soon as it is finished,
thou shalt have thy desire:
Command what you think good, my Lord,
I will thereto agree;
On this Condition, that the town
for ever may be free:
If thou thy Cloaths strip off,
and here lay them down;
And at Noon-day on Horse-back ride,
stark naked through the the town:
They shall be free for evermore▪
if thou wilt not do so;

• o • e Liberty th • n, now the •
• a • e,
• never will • estow.
The Lady at this strange demand,
was much abasht in mind;
And yet for to fulfil this thing▪
she never a whit repin'd:
UUherefo • e to all • fficers
of the town she sent;
That they perceiving her good will;
That on the day that she should ride,
all persons through the town▪
Should keep their Houses, shut their Doors,
and clap their windows do ••• :
So that no Creature young or old,
should in the Streets be seen;
Till she had ridden all about,
throughout the City clean:
And when the day of Riding • ame,
no person did her see,
Saving her Lord, after which time,
the town was ever set free.

div.head: 5. How the Dukes Daughter of Cor •• al being Married unto King Locrin, was by him put away; and a strange Lady, whom he better Loved, he Married and made her his Queen; and how his Wife was avenged.
div.opener: To the Tune of, In Creete.

lg.l: WHen Humber in his wrathful rage,
King Albanack in field had slain,
Those bloody br ••• s for to aswage▪
King Locrin then apply'd his pain;
And with a Host of Brittans s • out,
At length he found King Humber out.
At vantage great he met him then,
and with his Host beset him so;
That he destroy'd his warlike men,
And Humber which for fear did • ye,
And being Drown'd in the Deep,
he left a Lady there alive,
UUhich sadly did lamen • and w • p,
for fear they should • er li • e depr •• e,
But by her face that was so fai • ,
The King was caught in Cupids snare.
Ye took this Lady to his Love,
So that the Queen did quickly prove,
the King did bear 〈◊〉 small good wi •• :
UUhich though by we • lock late b •• un,
He had by her a gallant Son.
Queen Guendoline was griev'd in mind,
At length the cause she than • 'd to find,
which brought her to most bitter woe:
By whom a Daughter he beg • t.
The Duke of Cornwal being dead,
the Father of that gallant Queen;
The King with Lust being overlaid,
his lawful wife he cast off clean:
UUho with her dear and tender • on,
For succour did in Cornwal run.
and made of her his lawful wife;
UUith her which was his hearts delight,
he thought to lead his life:
Thus Guendo • me, as one forlorn,
Did hold her wretched life in scorn.
But when the Cornish men did know,
the great abuse she did endure,
UUith her a number great did go,
which she by Prayers did procure:
In Battel then they Marcht along,
For to redress this grievous wrong.
And near a Rider▪ called Store,
the King with all his Host she met,
UUhere both the Armies fought full sore,
but yet the Queen the Field did get:
Yet • 're they did the Conquest gain,
The King was with an Arrow slain.
Then Guendoline did take in hand,
until her Son was come to age,
The Government of all the Land,
but first her fury to asswage:
She did command her Souldirs wild,
To drown both Estrild and her Child.

Inconti • e • tith ••
〈◊〉 they did brin • ,

And
• abri ••
Daughter to a King,
Into the River there was cast.
And ever since that running stream,

I • called Save ••
• hrough the Realm;

div.head: 6. A Song of Queen Isabel, Wife to King Edward the Second; how by the Spencers she was constrained secretly to go out of England with her eldest Son, Prince Edward, to seek for succour in France, and what happened • nto her in her Journey.

lg.l: PRoud were the Spencers, and of condition ill,
And many Lords and Nobles of the Land,
And at the last they did encrease truth grief,
Do that her life she dreaded wandrous sor •
And cast within her secret thoughts,
That she requests with counts nance grave and (sage)
That she to Thomas Beckets Youth,
Then being joyful to have that happy charice,
Her Son and she took Ship with speed,
And Royally she was receiued then,
By the King and all the rest,
And unto him at last she did express,
The cause of her Areiv •• there,
When as her Brother her grief did understand,
He gave her leave to gather men,
And made a promise to 〈◊〉 her eber • u • re,
As oft as she should standin need
But when indeed she did require its same,
And did proclaim, whilst matters were so,
That none on pain of death should go,
This alteration did greatly grieve the Queen,
That down along her lonely face,
When she perceiv'd her friends for look her so,
She knew not for her safety,
which way to turn or go:
But through good 〈◊〉 at last she then decreed,
some succour to this n • ed:
And to Sir John Henault the 〈◊〉 she,
And with great sorrow to him she then complain'd,
The sum whereof did greatly grieve
Who made an oath he would her Champion • e,
And in her 〈◊〉 spend his Blood,
from wrong to set her free
Shall help for to advance your state,
And in his promise most faithful he was found,
And many Lords of great account,
So setting forward with a •• odly train,
At length, through Gods special Grace,
At Harwich then, when they were ashore,
Of English Lords and Barrons bold,
there came to her great state
Which did reioyce the Queens afflicted hearts,
That English Lords in such sort,
came for to take her part.
When as King Edward hereof did understand,
How that the Queen with such a power,
And how his Nobles were gone to take her part
And with the Spencers unto Bristol go,
Leaving behind to govern London town,
whose pride was soon pull'd down.
The Mayor of London, with Citizens great store
The Bishop and the Spencers both,
Therefore they took him without fear or dread,
And at the Standard in Cheapside,
they sino • e off his head:
Unto the Queen then this Message they sent,
• herefore the Queen with all her company,
Did straight to Bristol march amain;
Then she Be •• teg'd the City round about,
to those that were so stout;
Wherefore the Townsmen, their Children, and their wives;
Did yield the City to the Queen.
Where was took, the story plain doth tell,
Sir Hugh Spencer, and with him,
This judgement just the Nobles did set down,
They should be drawn and hanged both,
Then was King Edward in the Castle there,
And Hugh Spencer still with him,
And being prepar'd from thence to sail away▪
But at last Sir John Beamount Knight,
Did bring his Sailing Ship to shore,
and so did stay their Flight:
And so these men were taken speedsly,
And brought as Prisoners to the Queen,
The Queen by counsel of the Lords and Barons bold,
there to be kept in hold:
And young Hugh Spencer that did much ill procure,
Was to the Marshal of the Post,
And then the Queen to Hereford took her way,
And here behold how Spencer was
From town to town, euen as the Queen
Upon a Iade which they by chance had found,
with legs and hands fast bound:
I writing paper along as he did go,
Upon his head he had to wear,
And to decide this Traytor lewd and ill,
Thus was he led along in every place,
When unto Hereford our Noble Queen was come,
She did assemble all the Lords,
and Knights both all and some;
And in their presence young Spencer judgement had
To be both hang'd and quartered,
Then was the King deposed of his Crown,
the Lords did cast him down;
And in his life his Son both wise and • age,
Was Crown'd King of fair England,

div.head: 7. A Song of the banishment of the two Dukes, of Hereford and Norfolk.
div.l: TWo Noble Dukes of great Renown,
that long had lived in Fame;
Through hateful envy were cast down,
and brought to sudden shame:
The Duke of Hereford was the one,
a prudent Prince and wise;
'Gainst whom such malice there was s • own
which soon in sight did rise.

lg.l: The Duke of Norfolk most untrue,
The Duke of Hereford greatly grew,
UUhich by his Grace was acted still,
Now he had a traytorous will,
The Duke of Hereford then in haste,
was sent for to the King;
And by the Lords in order plac'd,
UUho • ing guiltless of this crime,
〈◊〉 Duke of Norfolk at that time,
How can'st thou with a shameless face,
And here before his Royal Grace,
Did not these wicked treasons pass,
How that the King unworthy was,
Wherefore my gracious Lord, quoth he,
To whom I wish long life to be,
I do pronounce before you all,
A traytor to our Noble King,
as time shall shew it clear.
The Duke of Hereford hearing that,
And did return this answer flat,
The term of traytor, truthless Duke,
With flat distance to thy face,
And therefore if it please your Grace,
To Combat with my known Foe,
I do not doubt but plainly prove,
He hath most falsly sought my shame,
The King did grant this just request,
The Dukes on sturby Steebs full stout,
in Coats of Steel most bright;
With Spears in Rests, did enter Lists,
The King then east his Warden down,
And with his Lords he councel took,
At length unto these Noble Dukes,
And unto them with losty speech,
Our Noble King for special cause,
Shall part the Realm on pain of death,
while ten years space doth last
And Thomas Duke of Norfolk thou,
And therefore no good proof can bring,
I say for term of life.
By judgement of our Soveraign Lord,
which now in place doth stand,
Charging thee on pain of death,
Thou never tread on English ground,
so long as life doth last.
Thus were they sworn before the King,
The one should never come in place,
Then both the Dukes with heavy hearts,
Their uncouth streams of froward chance,
The Duke of Norfolk coming then,
The bitter tears fell down his cheeks,
and thus his moan did make:
Now let me sigh and sob my fill,
That inward pangs, with speed may burst,
Ah cursed man! whose loathed life
is held so much in scorn,
Now take thy leave and last adieu,
Which never more thou must behold,
Now happy should I account my self,
if death my heart had torn;
That I might have my Bones Entombd,
where I was bred and born:
Or that by Neptunes wrathful rage,
I might be prest to dye:
Whilst that sweet Englands pleasant banks,
How sweet a scent hath English ground,
How fair unto my outward sight,
seems every B • anch and Bough:
The fields and flowers, the trees and stones,
That in all other Countries • u • e,
the like I shall never find.
O that the Sun with shining face,
would stay his steed by strength;
That this same day might stretched be,
And that the true pe • formed Lyve,
That by the fountain of my eyes,
That I might grave my grievous Plaints,
But time I see with Eagles wings,
And dusky Clouds begin to dim,
The fatal hour it draweth on,
and call to catch me in;
And now in woful heart I feel,
But farewell all my Friends, which I
And England here I kiss thy ground,
Whereby to shew to all the world,
This being said, away he went,
And at the length with grief of heart,
The Noble Duke in doleful sort,
did lead his life in France,
And at the last, the mighty Lord
While that King Richard at the Wars,
Who brought the vile and great abuse,
which through his deeds did spring;
Deposed was, and then the Duke

div.head: 8. The noble Acts of Arthur of the Round Table.
div.opener: To the Tune of, Flying Fame.
div.l: When Arthur first in Court began,
and was approved King;
By force of Arms great Victories won,
and conquest home did bring:
Then into Brittain straight he came,
where fifty good and able
Knights, then repaired unto him,
which were of the Round Table.
And many Justs and Turnaments,
before them that were drest,
Where valiant Knights did then excel,
and far surmount the rest:
But one Sir Lancelot du lake,
who was approved well,
He in his fights and deeds of arms,
all others did excell.
When he had rested him a while,
to play, to game, and sport,
He thought he would to try himself,
in some adventurous sort:
He armed rode in Forrest wide,
and met a Damsel fair,
Who told him of adventures great,
whereto he gave good ear:
Why should I not, quoth Lancelot tho,
for that cause I came hither,
Thou seem'st (quoth she) a Knight right good,
and I will bring thee thither:
Whereas the mighty King doth dwell,
that now is of great fame,
Therefore tell me what Knight thou art,
and then what is your Name.
My name is Lancelot du Lake,
quoth she, it likes me than,
Here dwells a Knight, that never was,
e're matcht with any man:
• ho has in prison three score Knights,
and four that he has wound:
• nights of King Arthurs Court they be,
and of his Table Round:
〈◊〉 brought him to a River-side,
and also to a tree,
Thereon a Copper Bason hung,
his fellows Shields to see:
〈◊〉 struck so hard the Bason, broke,
when Tarquin heard the sound,
〈◊〉 drove a Horse before him straight,
whereon a Knight lay bound:
Sir Knight, then said Sir Lancelot tho,
bring me that Horse-load hither;
And lay him down and let him rest,
we'l try our force together:
And as I understand thou hast,
so far as thou art able;
Done great despite and shame,
unto the Knights of the Round Table.
• f thou be of the Table Round,
(quoth Tarquin speedily)
Both thee, and all thy fellowship,
I utterly deste:
That's overmuch, quoth Lancelot tho,
defend thee by and by;
They put their Spurs unto their Steeds,
and each at other slye.
They couch their Spears, and Horses can,
as though there had been thunder;
And each struck them amidst the shield,
wherewith they broke in sunder:
Their Horses backs brake under them,
the Knights were both aston'd,
To hold their Horses they made great haste,
to light upon the ground:
They took them to their Shields full fast,
thier Swords they drew out then;
With mighty strokes most eagerly,
each one at other ran:
They wounded were, and bled full sore,
for breath they both did stand;
And leaning on their Swords a while,
quoth Tarquin, hold thy hand,
And tell to me what I shall ask;
say on quoth Lancelot, tho,
Thou art quoth Tarquin, the best Knight
that ever I did know:
And like a Knight that I did hate,
so that thou be not he;
I will deliver all the rest,
and eke accord with thee:
That is well said, quoth Lancelot then,
but sith it must be so;
What is the Knight thou hatest so,
I pray thee to me shew.
His Name is Sir Lancelot du Lake,
he slew my Brother dear;
Him I suspect of all the rest,
I would I had him here:
Thy wish thou hast, but yet unknown,
I am Lancelot du Luke,
Now Knight of Arthurs Table Round,
King Hauds Son of Suewake:
And I desire thee, do thy worst,
Ho, ho, quoth Tarquin tho,
One of us two shall end our lives,
before that we do go:
If thou be Lancelot du Lake,
then welcome shalt thou be;
Wherefore see thou thy self defend,
for now I thee defte.
They buckled together so,
like two wild Boars rushing:
And with their Swords and Shields they ran,
at one another flashing:
The ground be • winkled was with Blood,
Tarquin began to faint:
For he gave back, and bore his Shield
so low, he did repent:
Then soon spied Sir Lancelot tho,
he leapt upon him then,
He pull'd him down upon his knee,
and rushing off his yelm:
And then he struck his Neck in •• o,
and when he had done so;
From prison, threescore Knights and four,
Lancelot delivered tho.

div.head: 9. A Song in Praise of Women, To a pleasant new Tune: called, My Vallentine.
div.l: AMongst all other things,
that God hath made beneath the Sky;
Most glorious to satisfie the curious eye,
of mortal men withal:
The sight of Eve,
Did soonest fit his fancy,
Whose courtesse and amity most speedily,
had caught his heart in thrall:
Whom he did love so dear,
A • plainly both appear,
He made her Queen of all the world,
and Mistris of his heart;
Though afterwards she wrought his woe,
his death and deadly smart.

lg.l: Which all men know, I need not shew, to high or low,
the case it is so plain,
• lthough that Eve committed then so great,
Why should not then, all mortal men,
And love their wives, even as their lives,
The Scripture doth commend, and say,
That night and day, she is a stray, from all decay;
To give her self a wandring,
Or flattering, or pratling, or any thing,
But all her mind is bent,
Her faithful love, doth not remove,
Then is not he, well blest think ye,
that meets with such a • ife?
I hear some men do say to me,
Few such there be, in each degree, and quality, at this day to be found;
Some men do set their whole delight,
Both day and night, with all despite, to brawl and fight,
But sure I think and say,
here comes no such to day;
Nor do I know of any she,
And yet for fear, I dare swear,
it is so hard a case:
For Maids, and wives, and Virgins all,
Both great or small, in Bowér or Hall, to pray I shall,
so long as life doth last;
With hearts content, and perfect peace,
That joys increase, may never cease, till death release,
the care that crept so fast,
To have them all in mind,
Even for her sake, that doth us make,
The glory of the Female kind,

div.head: 10. A Song in praise of a single Life.
div.opener: To the Tune of, The Ghosts hearse.
div.l: SOme do write of bloody wars,
Some do shew the several jars,
'twixt men through envy raised,
Some in praise of Princes write,
Some set their whole delight,
to her fair Beauty blazed:
Some other persons are mov'd,
for to praise where they are lov'd:
And let lovers praise beauty as they will,
other ways I am intended;
True Love is little regarded,
And often goes unrewarded:
Then to avoid all strife,
I'le resolve to lead a single life,
whereby the heart is not offended,
• what suit and service too,
Is used by them that wooe:
• what grief in heart and mind,
What for row we do find;
through womens fond behaviour:
Subject to suffer each hour,
and speeches sharp and sower:
And labour, love, & cost, perchance 'tis but all lost
and no way to be amended,
And so purchase pleasure,
And after repent at leisure;
Then to avoid all strife, &c.
To no man in wedded state,
Doth happen much debate,
except Gods special favour,
If his wife be proudly bent,
Or secretly consent,
to any lewd behaviour:
If • he be slothful or idle,
Or such as her tongue cannot bridle,
O then well were he,
Of death his bane would be:
no sorrow else can be amended,
For look how long he were living,
Evermore he would be grieving,
Then to avoid all strife, &c.
Married folks we often hear,
Even through their Children dear,
have many causes of sorrow;
If disobedient they be found,
Or false in any ground,
by their unlawful sorrows,
To see such wicked fellows,
shamefully come unto the Gallows,
Whom Parents with great care,
Nourished with dainty fare,
from their Cradle truly tended;
When as their Mothers before them,
doth curse the day that e're they bore them,
Then to avoid all strife, &c.
Do we then behold and see,
When men and wives agree,
and live together;
Where the Lord hath sent them eke,
Fair Children mild and meek,
like flowers in summer weather:
How greatly are they grieved,
And will not by joy he relieved,
if that Death doth call,
Either wife or Children small,
whom their vertues do command,
Their losses whom they thus added,
from their hearts cannot be moved,
Then to avoid all strife, &c.
Who being in that happy state,
Would work himself such hate,
his Fancy for to follow:
Or living here devoid of strife,
Would take him to a wife;
for to procure his sorrow,
With cárking and with caring,
Evermore must be sparing,
Were he not worse'then mad,
being merry would be sad:
Were he to be commended.
That e're would seek much pleasure,
where grief is all his treasure:
Then to avoid all strife, &c.

div.head: 11. The Widdows Solace.
div.opener: To the Tune of, Robinsons Almain.
div.l: MOurn no more fair Widdow,
thy tears are all in vain;
'Tis neither grief nor sorrow,
can call the dead again:
Man's well enough compared,
unto the Summers flower,
Which now is fair and pleasant,
yet withereth in an hour:
And mourn no more in vain,
as one whose faith is small;
Be patient in affliction,
and give God thanks for all.
All men are born to dye,
the Scripture telleth plain,
Of Earth we were created,
to Earth we must again,
I was neither Croesus treasure,
nor Alexanders fame:
Nor Solomon by wisdom,
that could Deaths fury tame;
〈◊〉 Physick might preserve them,
when nature did decay;
What man can hold for ever,
the thing that will away?
Then mourn no more, &c.
Though you have lost your Husband,
your comfort in distress;
Consider God regardeth
the Widdows heaviness:
And hath strictly charged,
such as his Children be,
The Fatherless and Widdow,
to shield from injury.
Then mourn no more, &c.
If he were true and faithful,
and loving unto thee;
Doubt not but there's in England,
enough as good as he:
But if that such affe • tion,
within this heart was none;
Then give God praise and glory,
that he is dead and gone:
And mourn no more, &c,
Receive such Suitors friendly,
as do resort to thee;
Respect not the outward person,
but the inward gravity:
And with advised judgement,
chuse him above the rest;
Whom thou by proof hast tried,
Then mourn no more, &c.
Then shalt thou live a life,
exempted from all annoy;
And whensoever it chanceth,
I pray God give thee joy:
And thus I make an end,
with true humility;
In hope my simple solace,
may well excepted be:
Then mourn no more, &c.

div.head: 12. A gentle Womans Complaint, in that she found her Friend Faithless, which should have continued Constant.
div.l: FAith is a Figure standing now for nought,
Faith is a fancy we ought to cast in thought:
Faith now adays, as all the world may see,
Resteth in few, and faith is fled from thee.
Is there any faith in strangers to be found,
Is there any faith lies hidden in the ground?
Is there any faith in men that buried be?
No, there is none, and Faith is fled from thee.
Fled is the Faith that might remain in any,
Fled is the Faith that should remain in many,
Fled is the Faith that should in any be,
Then farewel hope, for Faith is fled from thee.
From Faith I see that everyone is flying,
From Faith I see that all things are a dying;
They flye from faith that most in faith should be,
And faithless thou that brake thy faith to me.
Thee have I sought, but thee I could not find,
Thou of all others was most within my mind;
Thee have I left, and I alone will be,
Because I find that Faith is fled from thee.

div.head: 13. Of the Prince of England, who wooed the Kings Daughter of France, and how he was slain, and she afterwards Married to a Forrester.
div.opener: To the Tune of, Crimson Velvet.
div.l: IN the days of old,
When fair France did flourish,
Stories plainly told,
Lovers felt annoy;
The King a Daughter had,
Beautious, bright, and lovely,
Which made her Father glad,
she was his only joy:
A Prince of England came,
Whose Deeds did merit Fame,
he woo'd her long, and so at last,
Look what he did require,
She granted his desire,
their hearts in one were linkt so fast:
Which when her Father proved,
Lord how he ws moved,
and tormented in his mind;
He sought for to prevent them,
And to discontent them,
Fortune crosseth Lovers kind:
When the Princes twain,
Were thus barr'd of pleasure,
Through the Kings disdain,
which their joys withstood;
The Lady got up her cloaths,
Her Jewels, and her Treasure;
Having no remorse
of State or Royal Blood:
In homely poor array,
She got from Court away,
to meet her joy and hearts delight;
Who in a Forrest great,
Had taken up his seat,
to wait her comming in the night:
But to see what sudden danger,
To this Princely stranger,
chanced as he sat alone;
By Out-laws he was Robbed,
And with Poniard stobbed,
uttering many a dying groan.
The Princess arm'd by him,
And by true desire,
Mandring all the night,
without dread at all;
Still unknown she pass'd
In her strange attire,
Comming at the last,
in the ecchoes call:
You fair woods, quoth she,
Honoured may you be,
harbouring my hearts delight;
UUhich doth compass here,
My joy and only dear,
my trusty friend and Noble Right:
Sweet I come unto thee,
Sweet I come to woe thee,
that thou may'st not angry be;
For my long delaying,
And thy courteous staying,
'mends for all I'le make to thee.

lg.l: for why my life is at an end;
Loe here for thee I dye,
to shew I am a faithful Friend:
O hard hap that may be,
my heart blood lies on the ground •
UUith that he gave a groan,
that so like her love did speak;
And found when as she came,
all smeared in blood, which life did break.
While she cried out, my Darling,
I would that I had died for thee.
one sweet word of comfort give,
think in what great grief I live:
the Princess life was dead and gone;
add bright day was coming on.
And thus she made her moan,
all in dread and dreadful fear,
A fo • rester all in Green,
ranging the woods did find her there:
what hard hap brought you here?
here lies slain my Brother dear.
till his heart was set on fire;
you shall have your hearts desire.
He brought her to his Mother,
he sets forth the Maidens praise;
At last her love he gained,
in party colours strange to see;
The left side Cloth of Gold,
of woollen cloth still framed he.
this strange Deed in every place;
The King of France came thither,
in the woods the Part to chase:
asking how he durst be so bold,
To let his wife to wear,
in costly Robes and Cloath of Gold:
to the King thus did say;
• ell may they by their Bother,
being by birth a Princess gay.
The more I look, he said,
the more I call to mind:
and joyful tears did stop his speech:
straightway he dub'd her Husband Knight;
Then made him Earl of Flanders,
thus was his sorrows put to flight.

div.head: Of the faithful friendshid that lasted between two faithful friends.
div.opener: To the Tune of, flying fame,

lg.l: IN stately Rome sometimes did dwell,
Who had a Son of seemly shape,
When he was grown and come to age,
To send his Son to Athens fair,
And when he was to Athens come,
A place to board him with delight,
his friends di • well disce • n:

A Noble Knight of Athens Low •
▪
of him did take the charge,
Who had a Son Ganselo Ca • 'd,
just of his pi • ch and age.
In stature and in person both,
In quality and condi • ions • ke
So like they were in all resp • cts,
They were not known but by their names,
And as in favour they were found,
Even so they did most dearly l • ot,
Ganselo loved a La • y fair,
Who was in beauty p • erless 〈◊〉 ,
Upon a time it chanced so,
That he would visit for delight,
And to his true and faithful Friend,
Asking of him, if he would see,
To see the Lady which he lov'd,
But when he cast his Chrystial eyes,
The beauty of that Lady bright,
His gentle heart so wounded was,
And of his grief he knew not how,
For that he knew his Ladies Love,
Thus being sore perplext in mind,
Like one which death and deep despair,
His friend Ganselo that did see,
At length requested for to know,
With much ad • at length he told,
Who did relieve his inward woe,
Take courage then, dear friend, quoth he,
though she through love be mine;
My right I will resign to thee,
You know our favours are alike,
This day in mine apparel then,
And unto Church then shall you go,
Loe though my friends suppose'tis I,
He went that day and wedded plain,
But when the Nuptual feast was done,
That night they spent in pleasant sport,
and when the day was come,
A Poast for fair Alphonso come,
to fetch him home to Rome:
Then was the matter plainly prov'd,
And not Ganselo to that Dame,
Ganselo's friends and kind • ed all,
in such a rage did stay:
That they depriv'd him of his wealth,
And banished him their Country quite,
With sad and pensive thoughts alas,
Who was constrain'd through want to beg,
In this distress, oft would he say:
to Rome I mean to go,
To seek Alphonso, my dear Friend,
To Rome when poor Ganselo came,
Which was so famous, huge, and fair,
He was asham'd to shew himself,
if he would come this way.
Therefore he staid within the street,
his Friend that stood so nigh:
Which griev'd Ganselo to the heart,
quoth he, and is it so?
In desperate sort away he went,
And presently he drew his knife,
And being over weighed with grief,
While soundly there he sweetly slept,
And saw a naked knife lye by
this man so f • ll of grief:
The knife so bright, he took up straight,
And thrust it in a •• urehered man,
And afterwards he went with speed,
Into his hand that sleeping lay,
Which done, away in haste he ran,
That he indeed with that same knife,
To save his friend did say, himself
None, quoth Alphonso, kill'd the man,
And therefore set this poor man free,
Thus while for death these faithful friends,
The man before the Senate came,
which did the fa • t indeed.
Did say befo • e the Iudges plain,
none did the fa • t but he:
Thus when the truth was plainly told,
of all sides joy was seen;
In rich array he cloathed him,
And helpt him to his Lands • ga • n,
T • e Murtherer for telling truth,

div.head: THE SECOND PART OF THE GARLAND of GOOD-WILL,
1. A Pastoral Song
div.opener: to the Tune of, Hey ho holy-day.

lg.l: UPon a Down where Shepherd keep,
Two Country Maids were keeping Sheep,
Three Shepherds each on Daten Reed,
And so they were in number Five,
And we the like, let us contrive,
to sing their Song in order meet:
Fair Phillis part I take to me,

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Fye on the slights that men devise,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Hey ho, silly slights:

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: When s • mple Maids they would intice,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Maidens are young-mens chief delights:

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Nay, women they which with their eyes,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Eyes like bean • s of bur •• ng Sun:

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: And men once caught they soon dispise,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: So are Shepherds oft undone.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: If any young Man win a Maid,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Happy man is he;

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: By trusting him she is betray'd,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Fye upon such treachery:

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: If maids witch young-men with their guiles

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Hey ho, hey ho, guiters grief:

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: They deal like weeping Crocodiles,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: That murther men without relief.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: I know a silly Country Hind,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Hey ho, hey ho, silly Swain!

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: To whom fair Daphne proved kind,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Was he not kind to her again:

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: He vow'd to Pan with many an Dath,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Hey ho, hey ho, Shepherds God is he,

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Yet since he hath chang'd & broke his ruth,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Troth plight broke, will plagued be.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: She had deceived many a Swain,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Fye upon false deceit:

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: And plighted troth to them in vain,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: There can be no grief more great,

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Her measure was with measure paid,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Hey ho, hey ho, equal need?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: She was beguiled, that was betray'd,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: So shall all deceivers speed.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: If ever Maid were like to me,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Hey ho, hey ho, hard of heart!

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Both Love and Lovers scorn'd should be,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Scorners should be sure of smart:

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: If every Maid were of my mind,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Hey ho, hey ho, lovely sweet!

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: They to their Lovers should prove kind,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Kindness is for maidens meet.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Methinks Love is an idle toy,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Hey ho, hey ho, busie pain,

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Both wit and sense it doth annoy,
Both wit and sense thereby we gain:

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Tush Phillis, cease, be not so coy,

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Hey ho, hey ho, my disdain!

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I know you Love a Shepherds Boy,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Fye on that woman so can feign.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Well, Amarillis, now I yield,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Shepherd sweetly pipe aloud,

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Love conquers both in town and field,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Like a Tyrant fierce and proud:

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: The Evening-star is up we see,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: Vesper shines, we must away,

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.l: Would every Lady would agree,

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.l: So we endour Round-delay.

div.head: 2. Of Patient Grissel and a Noble Marquess, Tune is, The Brides Good morrow.

lg.l: A Noble Marquess as he did ride a hunting,
A proper Maiden as she did sit a spinning,
• ost fair and lovely, and of comely grace was she,
She sang most sweet with pleasant voice melodi-ously,
which set the Lords heart on fire,
The more he look • the more he might,
and to this dainty Damosel he went:
God speed (quoth he) thou famous flower,
fair Mistris of this homely Bower,
where love & vertue lives with sweet content.
With comely gesture, & mod • st fine behaviour,
She entertain'd him in faithful friendship manner
The Noble Marquess in his heart felt such fla ••
which set his seases all at strife;

When that the Marquess did see that they • er • bent thus
Who most dearly, tenderly, and intirely,

Great with child this Lady was,
And at length it came to pass,
two goodly Children at one birth she had;

Which did their Father well content,
and which did make their Mothers heart 〈◊〉 glad.
Great Royal feasting, were at these Childrens Christning,

And, when that all these pleasant sportings quite were done,

Now that th • Babes must ••• thered be,

She often wishes, with many sorrowful kisses,
that she might help their h ••• s

never shall I see you again,

Had I been born of Royal 〈◊〉 ,

He took the Children, and to his Noble Master
he brought them forth with speed;
Who secretly sent them unto a Noble Lady,
Then to fair Grissel with a heavy heart he goes,
where she sat mildly all alone,
A pleasant gesture and a lovely look the shews,
as if grief she had never known:
What thinks fair Grissel of the same
sweet Grissel now declare thy 〈◊〉 me,

My Nobles 〈◊〉 , fair Grissel at thy honour
and I no joy can have;

and as thou came •• to me,
now all thy cloathing must be
the poorest life must now content thy mind;
A Great to thee I may not give,
Thee to maintain while I do live,
against my Grissel such great foes I find.
When gentle Grissel heard these woeful tydings
the tears stood in her eyes;
She nothing said, no words of discontentment
Her velvet Gown most patiently she stript off,
her Girdle of Silk of the same;
Her russet gown was brought again with many a scoff,
to bear them all her self did frame:
When she was drest in this array,
And ready was to part away,
God send long life unto my Lord, quoth she;
Let no offence he sound in this,
to give my Lord a parting kiss;
with watry eyes, farewel my dear, quoth he.
From stately Pallace unto her Fathers Cottage
Full fifteen winters she liv'd there contented,
And at that time through all the land the speeches went,
Unto a Noble Lady of high descent,
and to the same all parties did agree:
The Marquess sent for Grissel fair,
that nothing should therein he found awry:
The Bride was with her Brother come,
Which was great joy to all and some,
and Grissel took all this most patiently.
And in the morning when that they should be wedded
Grissel was charged, in Princely manner,
• ost willingly she gave consent unto the same,
the Bride in her bravery was drest,
And presently the noble Marquess thither came,
with all the Ladies at his request:
Oh Grissel I would ask be thee,
•• to this Match thou would'& agree,
methinks thy looks 〈◊〉 wared wondrous coy:

div.head: A pleasant Dialogue between plain Truth, and blind Ignorance.

lg.head: Ignorance.
lg.l: Chill tell thee by my vazen,
stand here of Brick and Stone,
as ich may zay to thee:

lg.head: Ignorance.
lg.l: Ah, ah, che zmell thee now man,
che know well what thou art;
che wis not worth a vart:
Nor when we had the old Law,

lg.head: Ignorance.
lg.l: A Bushell of the best Wheat,
that were both good and new;
And this zhe zay my zelf have zeen,
and yet ich am no Jew.

lg.head: Truth.
lg.l: That we should be self lovers,
that makes the grief to hold.

lg.head: Ignorance.
lg.l: Chill tell thee my opinion plain,
and choul that well ye knew;
Ich care not for the Bible Book,
Zuch pritty Prayers as there be,

lg.head: Ignorance.
lg.l: Cham zure they are not voolish,
that made the Pass the trow;
Here not our Wathers wise men,
and they did like it well?

Have wisht the Light that you have,
For what art thou the better,
that they sing in the Quire:

And then to see the Roodlo ••
And now to zee them wandring,

The one was found a Traytor,

when they were with • s still:

div.head: 3. The overthrow of proud Holofornes and the Triumph of vertuous Queen Iudith.

lg.l: We sent forth many men of War,
To plague and spoil the world throughout,
That would not fear and honour him,
Their Towns and stately Cities strong,
That they had thus prepar'd themselves,
Quoth he, what God is able now,
to keep these men from me?
Is there a greater then our King,
whom all men fear to see?
Come march with me, therefore he said,
with speed let us be gone:
I will destroy each Mothers Son
Their God shall not deliver them,
On foot he planted up and down,
Twelve t • ousand more on Horses brave
He stopt their springs and water-pipes,
When four and thirty days they had,
The poor Bethulians at that time,
That they were like to starve and dye,
they were both weak and faint,
The People against the Rulers cry,
Better it is for us, quoth they,
Then by this great and grievous thirst,
O render up the Town therefore,
There is no means to escape these hands,
When as their grievous Rulers heard,
Good people be content, said they,
Yet five days stay in hope of health,
But if by then, no succour come,
Why tempt ye God so sore, she said,
Whom mortal men in Conscience ought,
If you will grant me leave, quoth she,
But what I there intend to do,
Go then in peace, fait Dame, they said,
and God be still with thee.
When she from them was gotten • ome,
She called to her the chiefest Maid,
that on her then did wait:
Bring me my best attire, quoth she,
And wash me with the finest Balmes,
The fairest and the richest Robe,
Upon her dainty Corps she put,
and eke her Hair did dress,
With costly Pearls, and precious Stones,
That like an Angel she did seem,
A Pot of sweet and pleasant Oyl,
she took with her that time;
A Bag of Figs, and fine Wheat flower,
Because she would not eat with them,
And from the City thus she went,
Much ground alas, she had not gone,
From whence came you fair Maid, quoth they,
and where walk you so late?
From yonder Town, good sir, quoth she,
unto your Lord of high estate.
When they did mark and view her well,
They were amazed in their minds,
so fair a Dame to see;
They set her in a Chariot then,
To wait on Princely Judith there,
And all the Souldiers running came,
to view her, as she went;
And thus with her they past along,
Then came this stately Guard in haste,
And to their high renowned Lord,
Her beauty bright made him to muse,
Rise up Renowned Dame, quoth he,
And be no whit adasht at all,
UUhen she had uttered her intent,
by love was brought in thrall.
And bearing in his lofty breast,
He granted every thing to her,
Each night therefore he gave • er 〈◊〉 ,
which she had made that day.
UUhen she in Camp had three days been,
Fair Dame, quoth he, my Lord commands
Quoth she, I will not my Lord
A very great and sumtuous Feast,
They laid him down, and Judith their
When all the Doors about were s • ut,
Hard by the Pillow of his 〈◊〉 ,
She cut his Head from 〈…〉 quite,
and gave it to her Maid.
She took the same with her likewise▪
And thus through all the Court of Guards,
None did her stay, thinking that she
When she had past, escap'd quite
And that she was come, near unto
Come open me the Gates, quoth she,
our Foe the Lord hath slain;
See here his Head within my hand,
that bore so great a Fame.
Upon a Pole they pifcht his Head,
that all men might it spy;
And o're the City wall forthwith,
Then all the Souldiers in the town,
But sure their Foes spy'd their approach,
They found his liveless Body there,
UUhen this was known, all in amaze,
They left their tents full rich behind,
• o here, behold, how God provides,
for them that in him trust;
UUhen earthly hope is all in vain,
he takes us from the dust:
How often hath our Judith sav'd
as may he seen this day.

div.head: 5. A Princely Ditty, in praise of the English ROSE. Translated out of French.

lg.l: UUithin my eye, none doth come nigh,
the sweet Red Rose of England:
But yet the famous flower of France,
doth honour the Rose of England.
A s I abroad was walking,
I heard the small Birds •• l king:
And every one did frau • her s • ng,
in praise of the Rose of England.
But he were blest, that may hear in his breast,
the sweet Red Rose of England,
Whilst I do ring on every string,
the praise of the Rose of England.
Did never smell a quarter so well,
as doth the Rose of England.
That ever my heart doth power:
None may be compared to thee,
which art the fair Rose of England.

div.head: 6. A Communication between Fancy and desire.

lg.l: I pray thee shew thy Name,
in pomp and pride of May,
Tell me, who was thy Nurse?
What was thy Meat and dainty Food?
sad sighs and great A • noys.
What had'st thou for to Drink?
What Cradle wast thou rocked in?
sweet Speech, which likes me best,
Tell me where is thy dwelling place?
What thing doth please thee most?
UUhom dost thou think to be thy Foe?
UUhere doth desire delight to live?
No, no, Desire both lives and dyes,
thou art no meat for me;
with such a one as thee.

div.head: THE THIRD PART OF THE GARLAND of GOOD-WILL.
Song. 1.

lg.l: A Maids Choice, 'twixt Age and Youth.
Youth is wild, and Age is lame:
Youth is wild, and Age is tame;
O my Love, my Lord is Young,
for methinks thou stay'st too long.
thou canst not give what I require:
For Old Age I care not,
Come my love and spare not,
Age is Feeble, Youth is strong,
for methinks thou stay? & too long.
and so consu • ie the chearful • oy;
O stay a while with me,
Till I my Love may see;
O Youth thou dost so long delay:
I would not lose an hour,
The Birds with sweeter Ro • ts▪
to entertain my love this way.
would receive him by the hand:
If he gave not me a fall,
and all unto my word would stand.
on thy command I wholly rest,
Do what thou wilt to me,
and be not strange to my request:
though I be conquered what care I,
Come meet me if you dare,
who first mislikes, let them cry.
AS you came from the Holy Land,
Met you not with my true Love,
by the way as you came?
How should I know your true Love,
that have met many a one;
As I came from the Holy Land,
that have come, that have gone.
She is neither white nor Brown,
There is none hath a Form so Divine,
on the Earth, in the Air:
Such a one did I meet (good sir)
UUho like a Queen did appear;
in her Gate, in her Grace.
She hath left me here all alone,
UUho sometimes lov'd me as her life,
UUhat's the cause she hath left thee alone,.
and a new way doth take,
That sometime did love thee as her self,
and her joy did thee make?
I loved her all my youth,
but now am Old as you see,
Love liketh not the Falling Fruit,
He is blind, he is not deaf, when he 〈◊〉 ,
For love is a great delight,
And yet a tru •• less joy,
he is won with a word of Despair;
And is lost with a Ioy •
such is the Love of Women-kind:
But Love is a durable fire,
Never Sick, never Dead, never Cold,

div.head: 4. Of King Edward the Third, and the fair Countess of Salisbury; setting forth her constancy and endless glory.

lg.l: WHen as Edward the third did live,
And burnt Newcastle to the ground,
And by the force of warlike men,
besieg'd therein a gallant fair Lady,
While that her Husband was in France;
the Noble and Famous Earl of Salisbury.
Who like a Lyon in a rage,
For to deliver that fair Lady,
But when the Scotish-men did hear her say,
Edward our King was come that d • y:
they raised their siege and ran away with speed
So when th • t he did 〈◊〉 come
With warlike Trumpet, • ife and • rum,
none but a gallant Lady did him meet.
Who when he did with greedy eyes
And ever the longer that he lookt;
For in her only beauty was
And humbly then upon her knees,
that he had driven danger from her gate:
Lady, quoth he, stand up in peace,
Although my war doth now encrease,
Lord keep (quoth she) all hurt from • our • state
Now is the King full sadin soul,
And for the love of the fair Countess
She little knowing his cause of g • ief,
I have • een wrong'd, fair Dame (quoth he)
no, God 〈◊〉 , my Sov • raign, she said,
If I were worthy for to kn • w,
The cause and ground of this your woe;
you should be helpt, if it did lye in me.
Swear to perform thy word to me,
To thee the sorrows of my heart,
I swear by all the Saints in Heaven,
And let my Lord have no mistrust
Then take thy self a •• de, he said,
For why, thy beauty hath betray'd;
Wounding a King with thy • right shining eye,
If thou •• then some mercy show,
Thou shalt expel a Princely woe:
so shall I live, or else in sorrow • ye.
You have your 〈◊〉 , my • overaign Lord,
Take all the leave that I can 〈◊〉
But on thy Beauty all my ioys
Take thou my Beauty from my face,
Did'st thou not swear to grant my will,
All that I may, I will ful • l:
then for my love, let my true love be seen,
My Lord your speech I might reprove,
You cannot give to me your love,
for that belongs unto your Queen.
But I suppose your Grace did this,
Whether a wanton Tale might tempt
Nor from your self therefore my Liege
But from your wanton tempting Tale,
O turn again my Lady bright,
Come unto me my hearts delight;
Yere comes the Earl of Warwick he,
The Father of this fair Lady,
my mind to him I mean for to impart.
• hy is my Lord and Soveraign King,
Because that I have lost the thing
What thing is that any gra • ious Lord
It is my 〈◊〉 which to near 〈◊〉
Curst be that fire and frosttho,
That caused this your Highness wo • :
O Warwick! thou 〈◊〉 wrong me very 〈◊〉
It is thy Daughter Noble Earl,
which kills my heart, yet do I her adore.
If that be all (my gracious King)
I will perswade the sco • nful Dame
Never shall she my Daughter be,
The Love and favour of a King,
And quits contrary he did say,
A message I must do to thee,
our Royal King most 〈…〉 thee gre •• .
The King will dye, lest thou to him
It is right Charity to love
But no true love, so charitable,
His Greatness may hear out the shame,
But his kingdom cannot buy out the blame,
It is my duty to move this,
But not thy honesty to yield, I wis,
I mean to dye a true unspotted Wife.
Now hast thou spoken my Daughter dear,
And when to thy wedded Lord
Then let my bitter curses still,
Then with a smiling chear go thou,
As right and reason doth allow,
yet shew the King thou bearest no Strumpets mind
I go dear Father, with a trice,
And by a slight of sine device,
I'le cause the King confess that I am unkind,
Here comes the Lady of my life,
My Father bids me Soveraign Lord,
And I consent, if you will gr • nt
I grant it thee, my Lady fair,
My Husband is alive you know,
First let me kill him e're I go,
and at your command I will ever be
Thy Husband now in France doth rest,
No, no, he lies within my breast;
and being so nigh, he will my fal •• od se • ,
With that she started from the King,
And desperately she thought to rid,
The King he started from the Chai • ,
O noble King, you have broke your word
Thou that not do this deed, quoth he,
Then never I will lye with thee;
• o, then live still, and let me bear the 〈◊〉 ;
Live in honour and high estate,
With thy true Lord and wedded mate,

div.head: 5. The Spanish Ladies love to an English Gentleman.

lg.l: WIll you hear a Spanish Lady,
Garments gay, as rich as may be,
deckt with jewels had she on:
As his prios • er there he kept her,
in his hands her life did lye:
Cupids hands did tye her faster,
by the likeing of her eye,
At the last there raine commandment,
for to set the Ladies free;
With their Jewels still ado • ned,
Alas then said the Lady gay,
O let me still sustain this kind
Leave me not within the City
Thou hast set this present day
But my heart in prison strong,
How should thou (fair Lady) love me,
whom thou know'st thy Countries Foe,
Thy fair words makes me sus • ect thee,
All the evil I think to thee,
God grant unto my self the same
Blessed be the time and season,
that you came on Spanish ground;
If you may our Foes be termed,
gentle foes we have you found:
With our Cities you have won,
Then to your Country bear away,
rest you still and weep no more;
Of fair Lovers there are plenty,
Spain doth yield a wondrous store:
Leave me not unto a Spaniard,
I am lovely, young, and tender,
Still to serve thee day and night,
It would be a shame, fair Lady,
for to hear a woman hence,
I will quickly change my self,
And like a Page i'le follow thee,
I have neither Gold nor Silver,
to maintain thee in this case,
as you know in every place.
My Chains and Jewels every one,
And eke five hundred pounds in Gold,
On the Seas are many dangers,
Which will be to Ladies dreadful,
and force tears from watry eyes:
Well in worth, I could endure
For I could find in heart to lose
a sweet Woman to my wife:
I will not falsifie my vow,
Nor yet for all the fairest Dames,
O how happy is that woman
that enjoys so true a friend;
Many days of joy God send you,
and of my suit i'le make an end:
Upon my knees I pardon crave,
Commend me to thy loving Lady,
bear to her this Chain of Gold,
And these Bracelets for a token,
grieving that I was so hold:
All my Jewels in like sort,
For these are fitting for thy wife,
I will spend my days in prayer,
Love and all her laws defies;
In a Nunnery will I shrew me,
But e're my Prayers h •• e 〈◊〉 and,
To pray for thee and for thy love,
though to thee my love was bent:
The like fall ever to thy share,

div.head: 9. A Farewel to Love.

lg.l: FArewel false Love, the Oracle of lies,
a mortal foe, an enemy to rest,
An envious Boy, from whence great cares arise,
A bastard vile, a beast with age possest:
A way for errour, a tempest full of treason,
In all respects contrary unto reason.
A poysoned Serpent cover'd all with flowers,
Mother of sighs, and Murtherers of repose;
A sea of sorrows, whence run all such showers:
As moisture gives to every grie •• that grows:
A school of guile, a nest of deep deceit:
A Golden hook that holds a poysoned 〈◊〉
A Fortress field, whom reason did defend,
A Syrens song, a server of the mind;
A Maze wherein affections find no end,
A raining cloud, that runs before the wind:
A Substance like the shaddow of the Sun,
A Cole of grief, for which the wisest run:
A quenchless fire, a rest of trembling fear,
A path that leads to peril and mishap,
A true retread of sorrow and despair,
An idle Boy, that sleeps in pleasures lap:
A deep mistrust of that which certain seems,
A hope of that which reason doubtful deems.
Then sith thy reign my younger years betray'd,
And for my Faith, Ingratitude I find;
And such repentance hath the wrong bewray'd,
Whose crooked cause hath not been after kind:
False love go back, and beauty frail adieu,
Dead is the root from which such fancies grew.

div.l: The lover by his gifts thinks to conquer chastity
And with his gifts sends these verses to his lady.

lg.l: What face so fair, that is not crackt with gold?
What wit so worth that hath in gold his wonder?
What learning but with golden lines doth hold?
what state so high, but gold could lying it under,
What thought so sweet, but Gold doth better seafo • ,
And what rule better then the golden reason?
The ground was fat that yields the golden fruit
The study high that sets the golden state:
The labour sweet that gets the golden suit:
The reckoning rich that scorns the Golden rate:
The love is sure that golden hoxe doth hold,
And rich again, that serves the God of Gold.

div.head: The Womans Answer.

lg.l: Foul is the face whose beauty gold can raft,
Worthless the wit that hath gold in her wonder;
Unlearned lines, puts gold in Honours place,
Wicked the state that will to coin come under:
Base the Conceit that seasoned is with Gold,
And Beggers rule that such a reason hold.
Earth gives the gold, but Heaven gives greater grace,
Men study wealth, but Angels wisdom raise;
Labour seeks peace, love hath an higher place,
Death makes the reckoning, life is all my race:
The hope is here, my hope of heaven doth hald,
God give me grace, let Dives dye with gold.
